column4: Column 4
What to Do (Exactly)

column2: NFRs clarification framework(latency, throughput, HA, etc)
column4: START HERE.1–2 hours. Practice asking: "How many users? Peak QPS? Reads/writes ratio?"
2–3 hours; practice: "Design Twitter → estimate tweets/sec → storage → bandwith"

column2: Basic networking (HTTP, REST, DNS, load balancers)
column4: 1–2 hours; you know this; crystallize explanations.
2–3 hours; design schemas for: User, Post, Order, Payment, Vehicle.

column2: SQL vs NoSQL tradeoffs (when to use which)
column4: 1–2 hours; Postgres vs MongoDB decision tree.
2–3 hours; understand leader/follower, read replicas, sharding keys, hotspots.

column2: CAP theorem & consistency models (strong vs eventual)
column4: 1–2 hours; intuitive explanations tied to real systems.

column2: Caching layers(CDN, in-memory cache, DB cache, strategies)
column4: 2–3 hours; cache-aside, write-through, invalidation patterns.
2–3 hours;your SQS/SNS expertise.Explain idempotency + retries + DLQ.
2–3 hours;your existing experience.Talk about your 3–4 real projects.
1–2 hours; draw flow diagrams.

column2: API design for scale(versioning, pagination, rate limits)
column4: 1–2 hours; you did "60% API performance improvement" ; explain deeply.
2–3 hours;fraud/biometric projects are gold here.Deep dive with examples.

column2: Web security in distributed systems (XSS, CSRF, DDoS mitigation)
column4: 1–2 hours; enterprise clients care .

column2: Idempotency, retries, rate limiting in APIs
column4: 2–3 hours; design with: "What if a request retries 5 times?"
3–4 hours mock; sketch → explain → discuss tradeoffs. (Your roadmap already has this)
3–4 hours mock; token bucket, sliding window, Redis impl. (Your roadmap)
4–5 hours mock; this is where you'll jump from 4→7. Multi-channel, user prefs, retries, observability.

column2: System Design Problem: Chat System(1:1 + online status)
column4: 4–5 hours mock; WebSocket, pub/sub, consistency.

column2: System Design Problem: Payment / Checkout System
column4: 4–5 hours mock;perfect for your domain.Idempotency, audit, security.
2–3 hours;your production war-room experience shines.Talk MTTR, SLOs.
1–2 hours; "How does the system survive if service X goes down?"
1–2 hours; Next.js + S3 integration patterns.
Skip for now unless a job asks for it.
1–2 hours; RTO/RPO, active-active setups.
2–3 hours; order lifecycle, saga pattern basics.

column2: Mock Interview Structure(how to conduct one)
column4: 1 hour study; then practice 1–2 mock interviews with friend/colleague.
Skip unless targeting SaaS (PayPay, Money Forward).
Skip; not critical for Japan roles.
Skip.
